author: piggydancer
body:
Billionaire investors also have a lot more to lose and a lot less to gain from taking large risks. That shouldn't be lost in the average retail investor. Investing with 1 billion should be different than investing with 10k. 

It doesn't surprise me that he and other large investors who manage money for incredibly wealthy clients have a lower threshold for risk. They should. As long as they out pace inflation and don't spend more than they make, they can afford to live for life times. 

Average investors need to grow their money. Wealthy investors need to protect theirs. Don't get caught up comparing yourself or following the path of someone with different goals.

author: HinduHamma
body:
Uncharted territory my fucking ass. 

All the sp500 has ever done is make new ATHs time after time , crash after crash. This time is not any different. This is normal. The speed at which it is recovering is also normal because every market participant knows the story of past US recessions and economic downturn - they know if you sell your holdings, you’ll regret it down the road. So what’s the point of selling right now if your actually investing for years, decades? None. Especially when it’s super easy to get a loan for rock bottom rates, cash is very accessible for all the big boy investors and institutions. 

Everyone constantly downvoted bulls in March for even thinking that a V shape market recovery was gonna happen, for ever thinking we were gonna see ATHs again this year. Don’t worry I haven’t forgotten. There’s a lot of remind me bot posts I got coming due soon from March . 

Once again bears, hold this L . Scoreboard don’t lie. You never win consistently. Keep being wrong and stay salty about this. I’m sorry you missed out on the greatest 50 day rally in stock market history. That’s gonna be a good story to tell your grand kids at least.

author: SolitaryEgg
body:
Yo seriously though, when did everyone here get so sensitive? When I am wrong and lose money, people on here mock me, and I laugh. I post my positions so people can call me a retard when I get shit on. It's all part of the game, baby. And it's fun. It adds a bit of SPICE to the market day.

But when I am right and make some jokes at others' expenses, people get *really* mad. Like, really mad. I've had multiple people send me hate PMs, try to doxx me, tag me for days straight to yell at me, etc etc. Like, jesus. It's not like I fucking know you. I'm not *actually* attacking you, personally.

I swear this sub didn't used to be this way. We used to laugh at retards, and the retards would laugh along. And, most importantly, all of us are the retards sometimes. But, now, good lord, people are so fucking defensive.

Is it the /r/all influx or something?

Anyway, I feel like people really shouldn't be here if they can't handle some pub-grade banter when they make a bad play. Shouldn't really even be trading.

Thank you for coming to my TEDx talk.

author: legendariers
body:
Must be the top. Back in 1929, right before the crash, a young girl wrote a letter to Standard Oil with $4 (or maybe it was $40) attached asking if they could invest the money for her. It ended up in the papers and sentimental readers funded a share for her to own. Then the stock market tanked.

EDIT: It was $4. She was trying to invest in Standard Oil of New Jersey, which reached a high of $37.25. The share was finally purchased just a few days before Black Tuesday.

author: s0kuba
body: The market traded sideways for almost 15 years from 1998-2013 in nominal terms, and CD rates paid better than dividends for the entire period.  I am a long-term believer in the market but some people forget how long downward cycles can take.  I have 75% of my net worth in private equity which is illiquid so I'm heavily net-long regardless of whether I want to be or not.  But I still call it like I see it and this market is starting to feel irrationally exuberant, especially given the tax changes on the horizon which knock out a meaningful % of EPS all by themselves.

author: htr_xorth
body:
Learn to be ok with not capitalizing on every stock you research.  I have refused to buy Tesla since $400 and I keep it on my watch list just as a test to my stock guidelines. Get used to fomo, embrace it as an unhealthy but normal feeling.  Just as people rush to buy lottery tickets as the prize pool grows.

I won't buy Tesla because it's too expensive.  I like Tesla.  I like Elon.  I want Tesla to succeed.  I'm happy for those who are bought in.   I feel the fomo, but I ignore it, I'm not going to buy a speculative stock for $900+, I'm just not.

author: MasterCookSwag
body:
I think something that everyone here should keep in mind is that this sub has damn near doubled in the last year and a half.  It's traffic more than doubled over the last three months.  Most of the commenters here are extremely new to markets and investing - they may be extremely confident in expressing their "analysis" but it doesn't change the fact that the overwhelming tide of thought here is coming from an extremely novice place.  The voting system only amplifies that.

I mean this genuinely when I say in the last three months almost every top comment in every front page thread has been either an outright wrong take or a very very surface level platitude.

You've probably seen this a lot but many of us repeat often that the stock market is not the economy.  When you see this sub push the rhetoric that the stock market right now has to be irrational because it isn't highly correlated with present day macro conditions you should take that as indicative of the broad inexperience present here rather than any sort of useful analysis of markets.  Your article puts figures to something a lot of us regulars have tried to tell people - the stock market is not the economy and it behaving out of lockstep with present day macro conditions is neither new nor unexpected.

author: VicarOfAstaldo
body:
In broad description, the market as a whole crashed. And before quickly recovering by and large for a number of reasons, a lot of people clearly looked at major companies and industries and thought, “well clearly this will recover soon it can’t fail it’s too much of a part of our civilization” and that kind of cascaded all over. 

And to the point we’re at they weren’t wrong. It was a fairly obvious observation that most likely sure, companies like delta for example will most likely recover their stock value at some point. 

And so they dumped a big chunk of their money into that and saw massive profits. 

Seeing a 50% return on stocks consistently for two months time is not normal. 

Almost always that is entirely the realm of luck and Id argue it’s the realm of luck borderline here. It’s normally essentially gambling. 

The amount of posts I’ve seen commenting something like “it’s not much” with 150% returns is **insane**

That’s not how stats or money or whatever you want to call it work. 

Sure if you are only investing $1000 that’s not a ton to many investors. But it doesn’t matter if you invested $3 it’s still a figure to be proud of. 

The amount of people who suggest their essential doubling of their money “isn’t much” isn’t healthy. 

That’s not normally how that works and the expectation  of anything near that over the next many years is going to breed the behavior of a gambler.

author: MrStealYoBeef
body:
Options are contracts.  They are not stocks, they are a contract stating that the holder has the right (the choice, or the *option*) to purchase/sell 100 shares of a specific stock at a specific price on a specific date.  Calls are for purchasing 100 shares on a later date, puts are for selling 100 shares on a later date.

Let's say a stock, we'll call them AAAA for simplicity, is at $100 today.  If you were to buy 10 shares of this company, that would cost you $1000.  You would own 10 shares of that company for $1000 though.  If you instead buy options, you would likely be able to get a couple options instead for the same price.  Let's say that a $100 call on AAAA for next friday costs $5 per share, or $500 per contract.  For that same $1000, you could have 2 calls on AAAA.

In both scenarios, you're looking for the value of the stock to go up obviously.  If you have 10 shares and AAAA goes up one dollar, you gained 10 dollars.  If you have 2 calls (which is 200 shares worth of an option) and AAAA goes up by a dollar, those calls increase in value as well, although not quite as much, we'll say it increases by $0.50 per share.  That's still a lot.  Instead of making $10 from your $1000 investment, you made $100 instead.  It's not quite that simple though.

Calls (and puts) have an expiration date.  If the call is expiring on the 12th (next Friday), then the value of the stock needs to be decently close or above the value stated in the contract, or the "strike price".  In our $100 AAAA calls, if the stock goes below $100 (especially on the Thursday), the value of the call will plummet.  And remember, since these are just contracts, you don't actually own anything with the money you spent.

Since you also spent $5 per share in order to get the call, the value of AAAA needs to not only be above $100 on the 12th to be redeemed (nobody should ever execute a right to buy at a higher than market price, obviously, you'd just be throwing away money for no reason) but it needs to be above $105 in order to make a profit.  You had already paid $5 per share for the right to buy those shares later at $100 per share.

Next, and here's what many people do in order to make their profit instead, *you do not have to hold your contracts.*  If you buy a call on Monday, you don't have to wait until it expires on Friday to make money.  If AAAA jumps to $120 on Tuesday, you could sell your 2 calls for likely $23-$24 per share.  That would turn a $1000 investment into $4600.  What a hell of a gain, right?  If you just had 10 shares, you'd have only made $200 on a 20% stock jump when people who are options trading just made a $3600 or a 460% return.

Lastly, the reason that so many people avoid them.  *Options can expire* ***worthless***.  If the stock drops to $95 on Tuesday, those calls are suddenly only $2 per share, you just lost $600.  If it drops again to $90 on Wednesday, those calls are suddenly less than $1 per share, you're at an $800+ loss.  If you had 10 shares, you'd have only lost $100.  On Friday if you still have those calls, if AAAA never hits $100, your calls will expire and you'll have lost the full $1000 investment with absolutely nothing to show for it.  That money is gone for good, no amount of wishful thinking is going to make it come back to you.

Puts are the opposite of calls in a way, they're the right to sell 100 shares at a certain price.  You get a put when you believe the value of the stock is going to drop.  Let's say you have a $100 put on AAAA and the stock drops to $80 on Friday.  On Friday, you would purchase 100 shares of AAAA at market value ($80, or $8000 worth) and then immediately sell it to whoever wrote the contract for $100 per share, or $10000.  That's quite a profit right there too, you made money when a stock decreased in value.  You can't really do that with standard stock trading.  Puts do still come with the same risk as calls in the fact that they too can expire worthless if the value of the stock is above the strike price.  If you have a $100 put on AAAA and the value on Friday is $105, it would be absolutely stupid to purchase 100 shares at $105 to sell them immediately for $100.  Remember, these contracts give you the *option* to buy/sell at a certain price, it doesn't mean that you have to when they expire.

I hope that helps!  If you've got more questions, I'd be happy to answer them to the best of my ability.

author: Fr33Flow
body: I remember when I was a kid, I found a cat stuck in a tree.  He kept meowing and meowing for someone to save him. I climbed the tree and it took 30 minutes to get him down. Instantly me at that cat had a bond. I must have knocked on 30 different doors trying to find his home. But without a collar,  finding his owners was impossible. After asking all over the neighborhood I brought the cat back home where I knew my father would be waiting, wondering where I was. So I walked inside holding the cat, my dad was sitting on the couch and we locked eyes. You’ll never believe what he said. He said: “Son, what the fuck are shares???”

author: inlighttrading
body:
Well put! It's always refreshing to hear from the perspectives of learning traders who have *actually learned* something.

FOMO is one of the most dangerous Fears of Trading. This can be FOMO in anticipation or FOMO in reflection. In both cases, you feel a negative emotional reaction to missing or potentially missing a big move.

As you know, negative emotions are very bad as a trader and can limit your Trading Vision - preventing you from seeing a much clearer move that fits within your own defined strategy and risk tolerance.

There is no such thing as "missing out" in the stock market. There are infinite opportunities presented to you every single second. So focus on that. Focus on the stream of infinite opportunities and how you can interpret and decipher this data stream to pluck out trades within your own strategy boundaries.

Stick to your rules, manage your emotions, and focus on what is right in front of you.

**I'd love to hear some thoughts from other traders who very recently learned this lesson. What made you learn it? Was it a big trade that went wrong or a big trade you missed? I'd like to hear your story and your interpretation of the lesson you learned :)**

author: ez2remembercpl
body:
This isn't about options it's about life.

In my 20s  I worked a lot of fun jobs with no pay, mostly in the bar industry. By my early 30s I needed to get out and actually have a positive net worth, and sunk my life into one more bar (so fucking cliche', like a heist movie). It bombed.

***At 35 I was in debt, had no job, and was living in the spare bedroom of a friend in a room with no furniture besides a mattress.*** I also went online for dating (read: sex) and met a fabulous woman who turned my life around. We've been together for 15 years, I got an MBA and started making real money, and now I have actual investments, I'm semi-retired, and I have a great wife.

You can \*ALWAYS\* start over and succeed. My dad's girlfriend (yes, a 90 year old MF is a player) had stage 4 cancer in 2014 and a 6 months prognosis. She's the one who drives his half-blind ass around town because she's in pretty good shape to this day.

There is always hope until the last day.

author: Jsizzle19
body:
appreciate the clarification. the key really comes down to whether you want to be investing or gambling. You can get lucky, go on a nice streak and see your stocks rise a lot in a short period of time, but you’re playing with a house of cards.  you want your money to work for you. You may only have $1,300 now, but if you invest in a few, strong companies (profitable, strong balance sheets with positive free cash flow) or in an ETF / index fund where the stock prices will continue to increase over time, then each month or paycheck, set up a recurring deposit. Just like a 401k, you don’t want to touch the money. Just put it in there and try to forget about it (please note, there is nothing wrong with looking to
Rebalance your portfolio every so often) 

There are really 2 keys to investing: 1) always keep investing and 2) having the strength to stay in the game when the market drops 5-10%. 

You want to be in the game as long as possible. 
For example: if you invest $1,300 today with a $100 recurring monthly deposit and attain a 9% return (average annual return of the S&P 500), in 10 years you’ll have $22,050, in 20 years you’ll have $71,170, but in 30 years you’ll have $187,460. 

You want your investment earnings to keep compounding over time. The stock market should not be viewed as a get rich quick scheme

author: minos157

Every time I join these posts to defend TA it is with the notion that discipline and emotion free trading are the keys to success, not TA, not FA, not style, not length of holdings.  Find a strategy that works for you, and stick to the plan.  Don't let others tell you you're doing it the wrong way.

author: them_FIERCE
body:
Now let’s set aside the notion that stocks are allegedly suppose to trade at or anywhere near their valuations. 

DraftKings was able to make watching Soccer interesting to me. That is pure fucking wizardry. They hold the keys to a sports “betting” landscape that is practically untapped *globally*. Unlike casinos they have no risk exposure to outcome. They aren’t even classified as gambling in most countries because they make a legitimate argument that they are a game of skill not chance. So, no, tons of casinos are not just going to “make an app” and fart out profits. DraftKings has cornered the fantasy sports market, and if you haven’t looked at the financial trajectory of fantasy sports over the last 10 years...you done son. Pull back is def coming, so I hope your puts are reasonably placed because expecting the bottom to fall out just isn’t going to print.

author: Hotspur000
body:
Just my opinion, but some of the keys to being a day trader are:

1) Don't try to do too much. Focus on maybe 2 or 3 stocks that you think could move well in the day and go after them. If you're trying to do like 10 or 15 or something, you're splitting up your attention too much. This then directly leads to;

2) Don't be too greedy. If you earn some gains, take them. Prioritize ending the day up from where you started, even if it's by a smaller amount than you maybe would hope. I think a lot of day traders end up losing because they stay on a position too long, hoping for more, and then the floor falls out from under them.

And (again this is just personal opinion), don't play options. Options, to me, are just pure gambling and really stupid, because even if you take a chance on a stock and it doesn't pan out that day, well, at least, you own it, it's still an investment – six months later it might go up again and you can sell it them.
